quoteLast: All have to “vunula” first (put on their ornaments). They, of course, grease themselves well to make their dark bodies sleek and supple.
title: Some Zulu Customs and Folk-lore
author: Samuelson, L. H.

quoteFirst: Entering by way of the Sun-in Gate and passing through the Ch‘ang-kyŭng Palace they approached the Po-t‘ong Gate which gave entrance to the “Old Palace,” but they found it strongly guarded by Japanese. Here a sharp encounter took place which lasted an hour, beginning
quoteTime: about three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: . About ten each of the Chinese, Japanese and Koreans fell in this assault. As the darkness came on the Japanese began to fall back and taking the king and the newly appointed ministers they made their way to the extreme northeasterly portion of the palace grounds, not far from the Hong-wha Gate.
title: The History of Korea (vol. 2 of 2)
author: Hulbert, Homer B. (Homer Bezaleel), 1863-1949

quoteTime: About three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: two men covered with dust galloped up and cried, “Fly, fly! The house will be burned over your head!”
title: Women in American history
author: Humphrey, Grace, 1882-1961

quoteFirst: The _Impérieuse_ now rapidly approaching, gave the tower a gun and recalled the boats, in order to send other crews, those engaged in the chase being necessarily much fatigued.
quoteLast: we were joined by the Gibraltar privateer, which bore up to engage the tower, keeping up a smart fire, as did also the ship. The _Impérieuse_ now came to an anchor, and opened her broadside on the tower, which was soon silenced.
title: The autobiography of a seaman (volume 1 of 2)
author: Dundonald, Thomas Cochrane, Earl of, 1775-1860; Earp, George Butler [Compiler]; Jackson, William, active 1784?-1862 [Contributor]

quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: . In order to see what kind of money was in circulation in Belgium, I immediately bought some pears of a fruit-woman, and handed her half a franc (10 cents). You may imagine how I was perplexed when the lady handed me a dozen coins of various sizes and values, as my change.
title:
The Youthful Wanderer
An Account of a Tour through England, France, Belgium, Holland, Germany and the Rhine, Switzerland, Italy, and Egypt, Adapted to the Wants of Young Americans Taking Their First Glimpses at the Old World
author: Heffner, George H.

quoteFirst: Alice knocked at Mrs Toomey's door
title: The Prophet's Mantle
author: Nesbit, E. (Edith), 1858-1924; Bland, Hubert, 1856-1914

quoteFirst: Amid all this bustle and activity the Spaniards were startled by the appearance of two large French vessels[886] in the offing, evidently ready for action. It was no part of Menendez’ plan to engage them, and he waited till,
quoteLast: , they bore away for the St. John’s. Then he prepared to land in person. As his boat left the vessel with banners unfurled, amid the thunder of cannon and the sounds of warlike music, Mendoza Grajales, the first priest of St.
title:
Narrative and Critical History of America, Vol. 2 (of 8)
Spanish Explorations and Settlements in America from the Fifteenth to the Seventeenth Century
author: Winsor, Justin, 1831-1897 [Editor]

quoteLast: , anyway. It gets you in the back. Then I kinda got to run things--especially when pa’s cuckooed.”
title: Falcon, of Squawtooth
author: Hankins, Arthur Preston, 1880-1932

quoteLast: we again struck spoor.  It was apparently that of the large herd whose track we had crossed a few hours previously.  Now it led north-east, straight over the dune about a mile away on our right--the dune parallel to which we had been travelling for upwards of an hour.
title: Lodges in the Wilderness
author: Scully, W. C. (William Charles), 1855-1943

quoteTime: About three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , we sat down to rest on the bank of the creek. We had been there but a few minutes, when a good sized black bear came shambling along up the bank of the creek, looking for salmon.
title:
Cruisings in the Cascades
A Narrative of Travel, Exploration, Amateur Photography,
